reasoning: The critique targets a supporting inference in the paper’s case that unbounded linear views are “fussy”: that separability/linearity implies there is (effectively) a single locally value-efficient configuration that must be replicated, making the target very narrow. This is a meaningful piece of the linear-view argument but not the whole position (the paper also argues fussiness via scale requirements and fat-tailed value-efficiency), so centrality is moderate. The objection is fairly strong against that specific inference: additivity/separability does not entail uniqueness or sparsity of near-maximizers, and large equivalence classes/symmetries could make the set of near-optimal uses broad. However, it doesn’t directly engage the paper’s separate fat-tail and “most resources must be used” claims, so it weakens rather than collapses the linear-view fussiness conclusion. Most claims are correct as logical/possibility points; the main limitation is that it establishes a possibility (many near-optima) rather than showing it is likely under the paper’s assumed distribution. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little to no fluff.
title: Separability Does Not Imply Unique Optimization
